summary: This document contains a series of email communications from the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. It includes a request from Epstein's attorney for preservation of evidence, internal emails about his CPAP machine and a psychological reconstruction meeting, and notification of his death. The emails show internal MCC coordination and legal preservation efforts following Epstein's death. This document contains a series of email exchanges from 2019 related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) communications about his CPAP machine request, his mental capacity for disciplinary proceedings, and urgent requests from the U.S. Marshals Service for investigation reports following his death. It also references news reports about a missing video of Epstein's first suicide attempt. This document contains email correspondence from September 2019 regarding a meeting to discuss the 'Psychological Reconstruction' of inmate Jeffrey Epstein (ID #76318-054) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It also includes a forwarded email from July 2019 concerning Epstein's request for a CPAP machine and a November 2019 email regarding a FOIA request for investigation reports on Epstein's death. This document contains a series of emails from November 2019 and earlier, primarily concerning the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death and his conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes internal BOP communications about FOIA requests, a request for investigative reports on Epstein's death, an email about obtaining Epstein's pre-sentence report from Florida, complaints about his jail conditions from his attorney, and emails detailing his status changes (from suicide watch to psychological observation) and housing assignment in July 2019. This document contains email correspondence from July-August and November 2019 regarding the custody, status, and death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes internal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) communications about his removal from suicide watch, psychological observation, cell assignment, and the official press release announcing his death. A later email requests investigation reports related to his death. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons email correspondence from July 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes updates on his psychological and physical condition, logistical issues with his legal visits, and administrative notifications about his bail denial and a planned psychological reconstruction meeting. This document contains email correspondence from October 2019 regarding a scheduled meeting to review a psychological reconstruction report for inmate Jeffrey Epstein (76318-054). It also includes a forwarded email chain from July 2019 concerning the release of investigation documents and photographs related to the July 23, 2019 incident involving Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY. This document contains Bureau of Prisons photo sheets and memoranda detailing a possible suicide attempt by Jeffrey Epstein in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on July 23, 2019. It includes staff accounts of the incident, Epstein's allegations against his cellmate, and subsequent internal emails discussing media reports about the incident and Epstein's status. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. It includes an email from an Associate Warden at MCC New York describing the last contact with Epstein before his death, and emails discussing the Florida investigation into Epstein's prior incarceration and work release, including a formal request from the Palm Beach County Sheriff to Florida Governor Ron DeSantis for FDLE to take over the investigation. This document contains official Bureau of Prisons correspondence notifying the court of Jeffrey Epstein's death by apparent suicide on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes a detailed timeline of events surrounding his death, internal emails about the investigation, and a draft reconstruction report. The document reveals the immediate response, notifications to various agencies, and the initiation of investigations by the FBI and DOJ OIG. This is an interim psychological reconstruction report on the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Complex (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. The report details Epstein's background, institutional history, mental health assessments, antecedent circumstances, and identifies numerous procedural failures and inconsistencies in his supervision and care. It concludes with 14 recommendations for improving suicide prevention and inmate management. This document is a collection of email correspondence from August 2019 to January 2020, primarily between Bureau of Prisons staff and attorneys regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes complaints about his conditions, requests for his CPAP machine, and communications following his death, including an investigation request and a follow-up meeting. This document contains email correspondence from August to November 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes complaints from his attorneys about his conditions, official notification of his death to the court, and internal requests for investigation reports. The document reveals administrative communications between prison staff, attorneys, and law enforcement following Epstein's death. This is a Bureau of Prisons psychological reconstruction report on the suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The report details Epstein's background, institutional history, mental health assessments, antecedent circumstances, and provides numerous operational recommendations based on failures and inconsistencies in procedures, documentation, and supervision. This document contains email correspondence from July-August 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) and the immediate aftermath of his death. It includes requests from his attorney for bathroom access, phone calls, and meal arrangements, followed by frantic communications between prison officials and prosecutors after Epstein's reported suicide attempt and death. This document is a chain of emails from August 10, 2019, concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It reveals frantic communications between the U.S. Attorney's Office, the U.S. Marshals Service, and the Bureau of Prisons as officials sought basic information about Epstein's death. The document also includes a forwarded request from July 25, 2019, for investigative materials and photos related to Epstein's prior suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, and contains photo sheets from that incident. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons memoranda detailing a reported suicide attempt by Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes staff accounts of the incident, Epstein's allegations against his cellmate, and subsequent medical records, including the final resuscitation event on August 10, 2019, which led to his death. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Health Services clinical encounter notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 23-30, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details his medical complaints, including an incident on July 23 where he was found with a rope around his neck, subsequent neurological symptoms, and his refusal to discuss the event, only hinting his cellmate might be involved. A series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake and medical evaluations at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM) in July 2019. The documents detail his medical history, complaints, physical exams, and prescribed treatments in the weeks leading up to his death. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his intake medical screening, ongoing vital signs, diagnoses, medications, and medical orders from July 2019 to May 2020. It details his medical conditions, treatments, and the administrative process of his care while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical, dental, and psychological records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019 to May 2020. It includes medical duty status reports, medication summaries, dental exams, and psychological assessments conducted while Epstein was housed at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The records document his physical and mental health status, including a suicide risk assessment following an incident on July 23, 2019. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service notes from late July 2019, documenting daily clinical contacts and assessments of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC-NY). The notes detail his mental status, complaints about sleep and noise in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), his inability to recall how he sustained neck injuries, and a competency evaluation for a disciplinary process related to a 'tattooing or self-mutilation' incident report. This document contains Bureau of Prisons clinical notes and assessments for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 23-28, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details his placement on suicide watch after being found with a string around his neck, his subsequent psychological observations, his reported memory loss of the incident, his complaints about prison conditions, and his denial of suicidal intent. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychological service records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-24, 2019, while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes suicide risk assessments, clinical contacts, and administrative notes detailing his mental status, complaints about conditions, and the incident on July 23 where he was found with a string around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Suicide Risk Assessment for Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 9, 2019, the day after a court proceeding. The assessment, performed by a PhD/Chief Psychologist, concludes Epstein's acute suicide risk is low and chronic risk is absent, citing his future orientation, denial of suicidal ideation, and confidence in his attorney. It notes he was placed on precautionary psychological observation due to risk factors like his high-profile case and sex trafficking charges. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological and medical records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-10, 2019, while he was incarcerated at MCC New York. It includes a suicide risk assessment, intake screening, risk assessment for sexual abusiveness, and lab results, all concluding he was at low risk with no acute mental health issues. This is a Bureau of Prisons Psychological Reconstruction Report on the death of Jeffrey Epstein, dated May 14, 2020. It details his incarceration, mental health assessments, suicide risk factors, the circumstances of his death on August 10, 2019, and numerous institutional failures and procedural errors at MCC New York. The report includes findings and recommendations for improvement. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff scheduling and overtime assignment log for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, dated July 22-23, 2019. It details overtime sign-ups, cancellations, shift preferences, and post assignments, including references to posts like 'Suicide Watch' and 'ATTY CONF' (Attorney Conference). This document is a Bureau of Prisons staff scheduling log from July 22, 2019, showing overtime sign-ups, assignments, cancellations, and shift preferences for various posts at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It reveals the operational staffing activities on a single day, including numerous overtime entries for posts like SHU, Control, and various housing units. This document is a Bureau of Prisons overtime assignment log for the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, covering entries from July and August 2019. It details staff assignments, shift preferences, and mandated overtime, with numerous entries referencing staff being 'already working this watch' or unable to work. The log appears to be part of the records from the facility where Jeffrey Epstein was held. This document appears to be a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff assignment and overtime log for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, covering dates around August 10-11, 2019. It details overtime assignments, cancellations, and staff postings for various units including SHU (Special Housing Unit), dry cells, and control posts, which is significant as it relates to the period of Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death. This document is an overtime log from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, dated May 19, 2020, covering staff overtime assignments and actions for specific date ranges in July and August 2019. It details numerous overtime entries, including assignments, cancellations, and sign-ups for various posts and shifts, reflecting the operational activity at the facility during that period. This document appears to be a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff assignment and overtime sign-up log for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, covering dates in late July 2019. It details officer assignments to specific posts, including the Special Housing Unit (SHU), attorney conference rooms, and suicide watch, during the period when Jeffrey Epstein was incarcerated there. This document appears to be a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff assignment roster and overtime log for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, dated July 22, 2019. It details officer post assignments, shift changes, and overtime assignment/refusal actions, likely related to the period when Jeffrey Epstein was incarcerated there. This document is a series of daily staff assignment rosters for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, covering dates in July and August 2019. It details officer post assignments, shift changes, overtime, leave statuses (sick, annual, AWOL), and staffing levels. The rosters are administrative records showing the operational staffing of the facility during this period. This document is a daily assignment roster and shift change log for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, dated Saturday, August 10, 2019. It details staff post assignments, overtime, sick leave, annual leave, and shift changes for correctional officers and other personnel, reflecting the operational staffing on a specific day. This document is a collection of internal Bureau of Prisons memoranda, reports, and timelines related to the psychological reconstruction and institutional response following the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. It includes detailed suicide timelines, institutional updates, corrective action plans, and responses to findings from a psychological reconstruction report. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons administrative emails and a roster concerning bed book counts and inmate population monitoring at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details discrepancies in inmate housing assignments and identification records, with corrections being made on the spot. The document appears to be routine prison administration records from late 2019 and early 2020. This document is the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York's institutional response to a psychological reconstruction report on the suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein. It addresses 13 specific findings and recommendations from the reconstruction team, detailing corrective actions and policy changes implemented after Epstein's death on August 10, 2019. The response covers issues like single cell placement, rounds, cellmate assignments, documentation accuracy, telephone calls, direct observation, follow-up procedures, inmate accountability, attorney log books, AED inspections, post orders, staffing, and sex offense risk factor training. This document is a Bureau of Prisons report detailing the July 23, 2019 incident where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with a homemade noose in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes staff observations, medical assessments, and subsequent interviews with Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, concluding there was insufficient evidence of an assault and recommending no separation of the inmates. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons records related to Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at MCC New York. It includes an incident report detailing his suicide attempt by hanging on July 23, 2019, his prisoner remand form, arrest warrant, medical release form, property record, and custody alerts. The documents confirm his detention on sex trafficking charges and note his suicidal tendencies. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, including his chronological disciplinary record (showing no entries), inmate personal property record, prisoner remand forms, and inmate profile. It also includes an email chain from July 30, 2019, forwarding his '583' form (likely a custody classification form) among MCC New York staff. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Form 583 Report of Incident and related staff memoranda detailing the events of July 23, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found with a makeshift noose around his neck. The report documents the initial response, Epstein's medical condition, his subsequent allegations that his cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione tried to kill and extort him, and Tartaglione's account of the incident. This document contains Bureau of Prisons records from July 23, 2019, detailing staffing logs, a clinical encounter for Jeffrey Epstein after he was found with injuries in his cell, and photo sheets documenting the incident as a possible suicide attempt. The clinical notes describe Epstein's injuries and his lack of explanation for them.

events.title: Epstein's attempted suicide
events.description: An occurrence investigated as an attempted suicide by the MCC.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the MCC.

events.title: Preservation request sent
events.description: Attorney Martin G. Weinberg sends a comprehensive request to the MCC to preserve all evidence related to Epstein's detention and death.

events.title: CPAP machine inquiry
events.description: Attorney Jonathan Savella inquires about procedures for getting Epstein his CPAP machine.

events.title: Psychological reconstruction meeting scheduled
events.description: A meeting is scheduled to discuss the psychological reconstruction of inmate Epstein.

events.title: Epstein follow-up meeting scheduled
events.description: A follow-up meeting regarding Epstein is scheduled.

events.title: CPAP Machine Request
events.description: Email exchange regarding Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys attempting to get him his CPAP machine delivered to medical staff at the correctional facility.

events.title: Inquiry on Mental Capacity
events.description: An internal BOP email inquires whether inmate Jeffrey Epstein is mentally capable of proceeding with a disciplinary process.

events.title: Email on Epstein's Death
events.description: An email with the subject 'Jeffrey Epstein dead' is scheduled, referencing his death.

events.title: U.S. Marshals Request Death Reports
events.description: The U.S. Marshals Service Prisoner Operations Division urgently requests any reports prepared by the BOP in the investigation surrounding Epstein's death, with a deadline of the next day.

events.title: News on Missing Suicide Attempt Video
events.description: An email forwards news stories reporting that video footage of Jeffrey Epstein's first suicide attempt is missing, with links to CNBC and NY Daily News articles.

events.title: Psychological Reconstruction Meeting Scheduled
events.description: A meeting was scheduled for 12:30 PM to discuss the Psychological Reconstruction of inmate Jeffrey Epstein (#76318-054) in the Warden conference room.

events.title: FOIA Request for Death Investigation Reports
events.description: The U.S. Marshals Service (Prisoner Operations Division) requested any reports prepared in the investigation surrounding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The Bureau of Prisons Office of General Counsel responded that it was an active investigation and no report was prepared for release.

events.title: Epstein's Attorney Complains About Jail Conditions
events.description: Attorney Mariel Colon Miro emails MCC staff stating Epstein has no toilet paper, his CPAP machine was unplugged, and he has only had two monitored phone calls since arrival.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein is removed from suicide watch and stepped down to 'Psychological Observation' status. He is assessed and scheduled to be housed in SHU with inmate Cesar Sayoc.

events.title: USMS Requests Epstein Death Investigation Reports
events.description: The U.S. Marshals Service Prisoner Operations Division requests any reports prepared in the investigation surrounding Epstein's death from the BOP, with a deadline of November 6, 2019.

events.title: FOIA Denial for Epstein Records Appealed
events.description: A paralegal discusses the denial of Danielle Ivory's (NYT) FOIA request for Epstein records under exemptions, noting the appeal to the Office of Information Policy (OIP) and that release would interfere with active investigations.

events.title: Epstein Arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at the Metropolitan Correctional Center under pretrial status after being indicted for Sex Trafficking of Minors and Sex Trafficking Conspiracy.

events.title: Request for Death Investigation Reports
events.description: The U.S. Marshals Service Prisoner Operations Division requested any reports prepared in the investigation surrounding Epstein's death, with a deadline of the next day.

events.title: Epstein Bail Denial
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was not granted bail at a court hearing and returned to custody without incident.

events.title: Epstein Health Complaints
events.description: Epstein complained of numbness in his right arm and neck, and a running toilet in his cell. He was taken off Psych Observation but was pending placement in the SHU (Special Housing Unit).

events.title: Epstein CPAP Request
events.description: Epstein, citing sleep apnea impairing his memory of a neck injury, requested to stay in a safer area to use his CPAP machine for one night before returning to the SHU. The request was partially granted.

events.title: Psychological Reconstruction Meeting Scheduled
events.description: A follow-up meeting was scheduled to review responses for the Psychological Reconstruction of Inmate Epstein.

events.title: Incident involving Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: An incident involving inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, which prompted an investigation.

events.title: Document request by USAO SDNY
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (Criminal Division) requested documents and photographs related to the investigation of the July 23 incident involving Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Psychological Reconstruction Review Meeting
events.description: A follow-up meeting scheduled to review responses for the Psychological Reconstruction of inmate Jeffrey Epstein, to be held in the Warden conference room.

events.title: Epstein's Possible Suicide Attempt in MCC
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with an orange homemade cloth around his neck, unresponsive. Staff intervened, removed the noose, and transported him to a suicide watch unit.

events.title: Epstein Alleges Cellmate Attack and Extortion
events.description: After becoming responsive, Epstein told staff he believed his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been extorting him for a week, threatening to beat him up.

events.title: Media Report on Guard Checks Before Epstein Death
events.description: Internal email discusses a Breitbart news report alleging prison guards skipped mandatory checks before Jeffrey Epstein's death, with the sender expressing disbelief.

events.title: Last recorded contact with Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: An Associate Warden visited inmate Jeffrey Epstein in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein was with a cellmate, showed no signs of distress or suicidal ideation, and was planning to meet with his attorneys.

events.title: Florida Governor's Executive Order on Epstein Investigation
events.description: Governor Ron DeSantis issued Executive Order 19-183, formally requesting FDLE to assume the criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and reassigning the case from State Attorney David Aronberg to State Attorney Bruce Colton.

events.title: Sheriff's formal request to Governor
events.description: Palm Beach County Sheriff Ric L. Bradshaw sent a formal letter to Governor Ron DeSantis requesting the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) assume the criminal investigation into the Jeffrey Epstein case.

events.title: FDLE assumes lead investigation in Florida
events.description: A Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office sergeant emails that FDLE has assumed the lead role in the administrative review/criminal investigation regarding Epstein's time under PBSO care, and that investigative materials were turned over.

events.title: Investigation into prior Epstein incident concluded
events.description: A BOP supervisory attorney informs defense attorney Bruce Barket that an investigation into a prior incident involving Epstein (a suicide attempt) has concluded with no charges or disciplinary action against Barket's client, Nicholas Tartaglione.
personsInvolved: Supervisory Staff Attorney CLC New York Metropolitan Correctional Center

events.title: Epstein's Last Day
events.description: Epstein met with several attorneys in conference from 8:30 am until 6:45 pm. He was reported to be in 'good spirits' during a social call at 7:00 pm. His cellmate, Efrain Reyes, had departed for court and did not return.

events.title: Investigation Launch
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the FBI was notified and began an active investigation. The Attorney General also requested the DOJ Office of the Inspector General to investigate the incident.

events.title: Next of Kin Notification
events.description: Epstein's brother was notified of his death by the Case Management Coordinator at 11:00 am.

events.title: Evidence Collection
events.description: Computer hard drives were removed from the Special Housing Unit and replaced with new ones at 10:15 pm by the Computer Services Manager.

events.title: FOIA Request Denial
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons declined a request from the U.S. Marshals for investigation reports, citing an active and ongoing investigation and directing requests to the OIG, FBI, or Central Office.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Plea Agreement
events.description: Epstein entered a non-prosecution agreement and pleaded guilty to one count of Solicitation of Prostitution and one count of Procuring a Person Under the Age of 18 for Prostitution in Florida.

events.title: Federal Sex Trafficking Charges
events.description: Epstein was formally charged with Sex Trafficking Conspiracy and Sex Trafficking in the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Arrest at Teterboro Airport
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France, and transported to MCC New York.

events.title: Bail Denied
events.description: Judge Richard M. Berman denied Epstein's request for bail and pretrial release, remanding him to custody.

events.title: First Suicide Incident
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a piece of orange cloth around his neck, showing friction marks. He was placed on suicide watch. The motivation was never determined.

events.title: Court Documents Unsealed
events.description: Approximately 2,000 pages of documents from a defamation lawsuit involving Ghislaine Maxwell were unsealed, containing graphic allegations against Epstein and naming other high-profile figures.

events.title: Request for Investigation Documents
events.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney CLC sends a written request via email for 'any and all documents and other materials, including photographs, related to the investigation regarding the incident involving Jeffrey Epstein earlier this week.'

events.title: Epstein's Complaints About Conditions
events.description: Epstein's attorney, Mariel Colon Miro, complains to MCC staff that Epstein has no toilet paper, his CPAP machine was unplugged, and he has only had two monitored phone calls since arrival.

events.title: News of Epstein's Death
events.description: An email with the subject 'Convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein dead' is sent, containing a link to a New York Post article reporting his death.

events.title: BOP Investigation into Epstein's Death
events.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney CLC, assisting in the death investigation, emails to request Epstein's prison records from his prior incarceration in Florida.

events.title: Scheduled Epstein Follow-up Meeting
events.description: An 'Epstein Follow-up meeting' is scheduled for January 10, 2020, at 12:00 pm in the WCR (likely within MCC).

events.title: Attorney Complaints About Epstein's Conditions
events.description: Attorney Mariel Colon Miro complained to MCC staff that Epstein had no toilet paper, his CPAP machine was unplugged, and he had only made two monitored phone calls since his arrival.

events.title: Official Court Notification of Epstein's Death
events.description: The Warden of MCC New York sent an official letter via email to Chief Judge Colleen McMahon and Judge Richard M. Berman notifying them of Epstein's death.

events.title: Psychological Reconstruction Report Forwarded
events.description: An Assistant Director at the BOP forwarded an email with the subject "Psychological Reconstruction - Epstein #76318-054" and an attached PDF report.

events.title: Epstein Arrested
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France, and transported to MCC New York.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his SHU cell at approximately 6:33 a.m., pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m. at a local hospital. Ruled a suicide.

events.title: Attorney Requests for Epstein's Visitation Conditions
events.description: Epstein's attorney, Mariel Colon Miro, emails MCC staff requesting: 1) hourly bathroom access during legal visits, 2) two promised social phone calls, and 3) permission to eat lunch in the attorney conference room.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt and Death
events.description: Email chain reveals Epstein was taken by ambulance to the hospital after 'another apparent suicide attempt.' Later updates confirm he 'passed away.' The BOP issued a press release, causing frantic communication between prison officials and prosecutors.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was involved in a 'Possible Suicide Attempt' at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at 1:27 AM. The incident was investigated and photographed.

events.title: Request for Investigation Materials
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY Criminal Division requested documents and photographs related to the July 23, 2019, incident involving Jeffrey Epstein from the Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: Reported Suicide Attempt by Epstein
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff responded to Epstein's cell where he was found with an orange homemade rope/cloth around his neck, unresponsive but breathing. He was revived, placed on suicide watch, and later accused his cellmate of attempting to kill him.

events.title: Medical Evaluation of Epstein
events.description: Epstein was evaluated by medical staff, reporting he had been without his medications for a week, had numbness in his right arm, sleep apnea, hypertension, and other health issues. His CPAP machine was to be provided.

events.title: Epstein's Cardiac Arrest and Death
events.description: At approximately 6:35 a.m., staff responded to a medical emergency. Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell with bruising around his neck. CPR was performed, and he was intubated and transported to a local ER but was in asystole (cardiac arrest).

events.title: Epstein Found with Rope Around Neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He reported waking up "snorting" after going to drink water and claimed not to know how the marks occurred.

events.title: Epstein Hints Cellmate Involvement
events.description: During a medical follow-up, Epstein insinuated that the injuries on his neck "have to do with his room mate" but refused to elaborate, stating "I am not going to say anything."

events.title: Epstein Reports Right Arm Neurological Symptoms
events.description: Epstein reported waking up with a loss of control over his right arm for a few minutes, describing numbness and "pins and needles." This prompted medical evaluations and a cervical spine X-ray order.

events.title: Comprehensive Medical Evaluation
events.description: Epstein underwent a detailed medical encounter where he reported being without his medications for a week, right arm numbness from days prior, and sleep issues due to lack of his CPAP machine. New medications and lab tests were ordered.

events.title: Epstein's Initial Health Screen at NYM
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes an initial health screening upon intake at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York. His vital signs are taken, medical history is recorded, and initial lab tests are ordered.

events.title: Epstein's Chronic Care Physician Evaluation
events.description: Epstein is seen for a chronic care evaluation. He reports severe back pain (L4-L5 stenosis), hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, and constipation. Medications are prescribed and adjusted.

events.title: Follow-up Chronic Care Evaluation
events.description: A follow-up physician evaluation where Epstein's chronic conditions (hyperlipidemia, back pain, sleep apnea) are reassessed. New medication (Vascepa) is ordered for 180 days.

events.title: Medical Note Cosign
events.description: A health services note from July 23, 2019, is cosigned by an MD.

events.title: Epstein Intake Medical Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein underwent a comprehensive intake medical screening at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), including vital signs, immunization history review, and a physical exam.

events.title: Diagnosis of Multiple Health Issues
events.description: Medical providers diagnosed Epstein with several conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, low back pain, and neuralgia.

events.title: CPAP Machine Issued and Hypertension Diagnosis
events.description: A CPAP machine was issued for sleep apnea, and a diagnosis of essential hypertension was recorded. A modified diet for fish allergies was also formally requested.

events.title: Insulin Administration Orders
events.description: Medical orders were issued for subcutaneous regular insulin to be administered twice daily, then each morning, via a sliding scale, indicating management of elevated blood glucose.

events.title: Preparation for Hospital Transfer
events.description: A 'Local Hospital Transfer' form was generated, listing Epstein's active health problems (including 'R/O self inflicted injuries'), medications, and noting he was cleared for transfer.

events.title: Incident with string around neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck. He stated he did not remember anything about it, and it was unclear if he placed it there or someone else did.

events.title: Removal from Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was removed from Psychological Observation and returned to SHU, with a follow-up psychological session conducted to assess his adjustment.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment after US Marshal report
events.description: A suicide risk assessment was conducted after R&D staff reported that US Marshals asked Epstein to sign a form noting he had 'suicidal tendencies' when returning from court.

events.title: Follow-up psychological session in SHU
events.description: Epstein was seen for a follow-up session in SHU, reporting he was feeling okay, eating meals, and wanting to go to general population. He denied any mental health symptoms or suicidal ideation.

events.title: Dental health assessment
events.description: Epstein underwent a comprehensive dental health history screening and A&O exam, documenting various health problems including sleep apnea, hypertriglyceridemia, and constipation.

events.title: Epstein charged with self-mutilation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was charged with Bureau of Prisons code 228 (Tattooing or Self-Mutilation), resulting in incident report number 3282555.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A suicide risk assessment was conducted on Epstein where he denied any history of mental health treatment, suicidal ideation, or self-injurious behavior.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment for neck injury
events.description: A suicide risk assessment was conducted after Epstein was found with marks on his neck. The assessment noted it was unclear if he placed the string around his neck or if someone else did.

events.title: Daily psychological observation
events.description: Epstein was placed on daily psychological observation. Notes document his complaints, mental status, and interactions with staff and his attorneys.

events.title: Competency evaluation and observation discontinued
events.description: Epstein was evaluated and found competent to proceed with the disciplinary process. Psychological observation was formally discontinued.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours. This prompted his placement on Suicide Watch. The origin of the string (self-inflicted or by cellmate) was unclear.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Psychologist M, PsyD conducted a suicide risk assessment of Epstein after the incident. Epstein claimed no memory of the event, stating he last remembered getting a drink of water and then hearing himself snore.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: After a 31-hour suicide watch, psychologist Ph.D. conducted a post-watch report. Epstein adamantly denied suicidality, expressed commitment to his legal case, and was stepped down to Psychological Observation.

events.title: Psychological Observation Session
events.description: PhD/Chief Psychologist met with Epstein, who was in good spirits but continued to assert no memory of the neck incident. He complained about SHU conditions and requested housing in general population.

events.title: Final Documented Clinical Contact
events.description: PhD/Chief Psychologist saw Epstein, who was smiling and joking. He continued to report memory deficits about the neck marks, complained about SHU and legal visit procedures, and denied suicidal ideation.

events.title: Suicide Watch Initiated
events.description: A suicide watch was initiated for Jeffrey Epstein at 01:40 after he was found with the string around his neck. He was to be continuously observed by inmate companions and seen daily by psychology.

events.title: Placed in Administrative Detention/SHU
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on administrative detention status.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Epstein was seen for a precautionary suicide risk assessment after returning from court. He was found to have no acute psychopathology, no suicidality, and was classified as CARE1-MH (no significant mental illness).

events.title: Clinical Contact Regarding Prison Conditions
events.description: Epstein called for the chief psychologist during an attorney conference to complain about not receiving a spoon, soap, or promised phone calls in SHU.

events.title: Epstein Returns from Court
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from a court proceeding in the evening. The proceeding potentially gave him 'bad news regarding his legal situation,' prompting staff to place him on precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Previous Incarceration in Palm Beach
events.description: Epstein reports having previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on charges of soliciting prostitution.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein reports he is going to have a bail hearing on the Monday following the assessment and believes he will be released.

events.title: Epstein Intake and Risk Assessments
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes BOP psychological intake screening and a risk assessment for sexual abusiveness upon arrival at MCC New York. Staff are instructed to notify psychology upon his return from court.

events.title: Blood Work Collection
events.description: Blood samples are collected from Jeffrey Epstein for comprehensive chemistry and hematology testing.

events.title: Epstein Arrest and Incarceration
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon his return from Paris, France. He was transported to MCC New York and entered into custody.

events.title: Staff Overtime and Shift Scheduling
events.description: Extensive log of BOP staff signing up for, being assigned, bypassed, or removed from overtime shifts and making quarterly shift preferences for Q4 2019.

events.title: Staff Overtime Scheduling Activity

events.description: Log entries show staff being mandated to work, OT lists exhausted, and references to emergency treaty pickups and escorts to a local hospital.

events.title: Previous Incident/Attempt
events.description: Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell with abrasions on his neck and knee. An incident report for self-mutilation was written, but a Special Investigative Services (SIS) threat assessment was inconclusive as to whether it was self-directed violence, a fight, or an assault.

events.title: Last Full Day
events.description: Epstein met with attorneys throughout the day. His cellmate, Efrain Reyes, departed for court and did not return. In the evening, IDO R. Proto provided Epstein with a social call and reported he was in good spirits.

events.title: Psychological Reconstruction Report
events.description: A psychological reconstruction report on inmate Jeffrey Epstein's death was issued, leading to the institutional response memoranda dated January 2020.

events.title: Bed Book Count - Unit 11 South
events.description: A bed book count was conducted in Unit 11 South, revealing discrepancies in inmate bed assignments in SENTRY and missing bed book cards/IDs for several inmates. Corrections were made on the spot.

events.title: Bed Book Count - 9 South (SHU)
events.description: A bed book count was conducted on the Special Housing Unit (SHU) 9 South, finding inmates keyed to wrong cells and some still keyed in SHU after being removed. Corrections were made on the spot.

events.title: Bed Book Count - 5 North & 5 South
events.description: Rocco Lupo conducted bed book counts in units 5N and 5S. While 5N was in order, 5S had missing cards, cards for departed inmates, and inmates in improper cells. Issues were partially corrected.

events.title: First Possible Suicide Attempt by Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his SHU cell with an orange handmade cloth or string around his neck. He had abrasions on his neck and knee. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at MCC New York's Receiving and Discharge area at approximately 9:24 PM. His medical intake screening was conducted at 9:38 PM.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Denied Bail
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was denied bail, which was noted as a significant disappointment likely challenging his ability to adapt to incarceration.

events.title: Telephone Call to Karina Shaliak
events.description: Unit Manager Proto provided Jeffrey Epstein with a monitored telephone call to friend Karina Shaliak at 5:15 PM.

events.title: Psychological Reconstruction Report Dated
events.description: The psychological reconstruction of inmate Jeffrey Epstein's suicide, to which this document is a response, was dated September 17, 2019.

events.title: SHU Bed Book Count and Audit
events.description: A bed book count in Unit 9 South revealed discrepancies, including missing cards for inmate Steven Estevez and incorrect bed assignments for inmates Oscar Parada-Ramirez and Jerry Reyes.

events.title: Epstein Found with Homemade Noose
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., correctional staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein lying in a fetal position on his cell floor with a homemade fashioned noose around his neck. He was breathing heavily and responsive. Staff restrained him, and he was taken for medical examination, which revealed neck injuries consistent with the noose.

events.title: Interviews with Epstein and Tartaglione
events.description: SIS Staff separately interviewed Epstein and Tartaglione regarding the July 23 incident. Epstein claimed extreme fatigue and lack of memory, while Tartaglione described discovering Epstein and calling for help. Both stated they had no major issues, though Tartaglione recounted a prior tense conversation.

events.title: Epstein Placed in Administrative Detention
events.description: An Administrative Detention Order was issued, placing Jeffrey Epstein in Administrative Detention pending classification.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Attempt in MCC New York
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein attempted to hang himself in his cell (SHU M-Tier Cell 124) using an orange homemade rope. He was found by staff, unresponsive but breathing, and removed from the cell.

events.title: Arrest Warrant Issued for Epstein
events.description: A federal arrest warrant was issued for Jeffrey Epstein by Magistrate Judge Barbara Moskowitz, accusing him of sex trafficking conspiracy and sex trafficking of minors.

events.title: Epstein taken into custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's custody status is recorded as 'IN CUSTODY' as of this date.

events.title: Epstein admitted to MCC New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is formally admitted as an adult pre-sentenced inmate to the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: Email forwarding inmate Epstein's 583 form
events.description: An email is sent among MCC New York staff forwarding inmate Epstein's '583' form (likely a custody classification form) for review.

events.title: Inmate profile review
events.description: An inmate profile for Jeffrey Epstein is generated, showing his assignment details, charges, and status.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide Attempt / Incident in SHU
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with an orange homemade rope around his neck, appearing unresponsive. Staff removed the noose, provided aid, and transported him to the HA-Unit for suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Accuses Cellmate of Murder Attempt and Extortion
events.description: After becoming responsive, Epstein told staff he believed his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been attempting to extort money from him for a week, threatening to beat him up.

events.title: Tartaglione's Account of the Incident
events.description: Tartaglione stated he was asleep when he felt something hit his legs, turned on the light, and saw Epstein with a string around his neck. He then called the guards.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell in the Special Housing Unit with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor, at approximately 1:27 AM. He was assessed by health services, showed a circular line of erythema on his neck, and was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Clinical Injury Assessment
events.description: A clinical encounter was performed on Epstein at 06:20. He reported not knowing how the injury happened, was ambulatory and smiling, and had marks on his neck and left knee. The assessment notes "R/O self inflicted injuries."

events.title: Photo Documentation of Incident
events.description: Photo sheets were created by the Special Investigative Section documenting the "Possible Suicide Attempt" involving Epstein and his cellmate Tartaglione in the Special Housing Unit.

keyFacts: Attorney Martin G. Weinberg sent a detailed request to the MCC on August 11, 2019, for the preservation of all evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein's detention and death, including videos, logs, medical records, and any note found in his cell.
The request specifically seeks information about the period from midnight to 8 AM on August 10, 2019, and about a prior incident on July 23, 2019, investigated as an attempted suicide.
Internal MCC emails discuss logistical issues such as delivering a CPAP machine to Epstein and scheduling a meeting for his 'psychological reconstruction'.
An email from August 10, 2019, forwards a news article with the subject 'Convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein dead'.
The document shows the MCC's internal process for handling legal preservation requests, instructing staff to preserve material but directing formal production requests through FOIA.
Jeffrey Epstein's inmate number was 76318-054 at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).
In July 2019, Epstein's attorney, Jonathan Savella, was attempting to arrange delivery of a CPAP machine for him, indicating ongoing medical needs while in custody.

The U.S. Marshals Service made an urgent request to the BOP on November 5, 2019, for all reports on the investigation into Epstein's death, highlighting external law enforcement interest immediately after the incident.
An internal BOP email from July 23, 2019, questioned whether Epstein was mentally capable of participating in a disciplinary process, suggesting concerns about his mental state prior to his death.
In December 2019, news reports cited in an email indicated that video footage of Epstein's first suicide attempt was missing, raising early questions about the circumstances surrounding his death.
A meeting titled 'Psychological Reconstruction' was scheduled for inmate Jeffrey Epstein (#76318-054) on September 19, 2019.
Epstein's attorneys were involved in securing a CPAP machine for him in July 2019, indicating ongoing legal and medical coordination while in custody.

In November 2019, the U.S. Marshals Service formally requested investigation reports on Epstein's death, but the BOP stated it was an 'active and on-going investigation' and no report was prepared for release.
The email metadata shows the messages were later tagged as 'Responsive' and 'Flagged' in 2020, likely during document review processes related to investigations.
The document reveals internal BOP communications regarding Epstein's care and the official stance on releasing information about his death investigation.
The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and other agencies (OIG, FBI) were conducting an active investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death as of November 2019.
Epstein was removed from suicide watch and placed on 'Psychological Observation' on July 24, 2019, with plans to house him in SHU with inmate Cesar Sayoc.
Epstein's attorney complained about specific poor conditions in his cell at MCC in August 2019, including lack of toilet paper and an unplugged CPAP machine.

The BOP categorically denied FOIA requests for Epstein-related records (including video footage, documents on his suicide/attempt, and visitor logs) citing exemptions that release would interfere with ongoing investigations and prosecutions.

A Florida Sheriff's Office official stated that many Epstein files were destroyed per their records schedule before his arrest in New York, but agreed to search for and send any remaining pre-sentence report (PSR) documents.
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019, at approximately 6:30 a.m. and was later pronounced dead; the incident was investigated as an apparent suicide.
On July 24, 2019, Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and placed on 'Psychological Observation' status, a temporary designation for inmates with impaired mental status or functioning.
Epstein had a pending incident report for 'Self-Mutilation' and was scheduled to be celled with inmate Cesar Sayoc in the Special Housing Unit (SHU).
Epstein arrived at MCC New York on July 6, 2019, under pretrial status after being indicted for Sex Trafficking of Minors and Sex Trafficking Conspiracy.
On November 5, 2019, the U.S. Marshals Service urgently requested any BOP investigation reports on Epstein's death, highlighting an official investigation into the circumstances.
Jeffrey Epstein was denied bail on July 18, 2019, and remained in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.
In late July 2019, Epstein reported numbness in his arm and neck, and sleep apnea, and was on and off psychological observation while pending transfer to the Special Housing Unit (SHU).

Epstein's attorneys raised specific complaints about his treatment, including restricted bathroom access during legal visits, unfulfilled promises of phone calls, and inability to eat proper meals during all-day legal meetings.
A 'Psychological Reconstruction' of Epstein was being conducted, with a follow-up review meeting scheduled for October 16, 2019.
Internal BOP emails show administrative tracking and flagging of documents related to Epstein as 'Responsive' or 'Flagged' in 2020, indicating post-mortem review processes.
A psychological reconstruction of inmate Jeffrey Epstein (76318-054) was conducted, with a review meeting scheduled for October 16, 2019.
On July 25, 2019, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY Criminal Division requested investigation documents and photographs related to a July 23, 2019 incident involving Epstein.

The Bureau of Prisons staff, including a Supervisory Staff Attorney and a Regional Counsel, coordinated the release of memorandums and photos to the USAO with conditions against further dissemination.
The document metadata shows the emails were tagged and flagged as responsive (BOP01703.MXRADMI.MXRDOMI) in May 2020, indicating their relevance to an official inquiry.
The email correspondence involves multiple recipients identified by UUIDs, but no other real individual names are explicitly mentioned in the provided text.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his MCC cell with an orange homemade cloth around his neck in a possible suicide attempt.
Epstein later alleged his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been extorting him for money with threats of violence.
Staff memos note Epstein's inconsistent behavior, including pretending to be asleep and making statements about the incident.
Internal emails from August 2019 discuss media reports that prison guards skipped mandatory checks prior to Epstein's death.
An email from July 24, 2019, states Epstein was removed from suicide watch and was to be celled with Cesar Sayoc, who was in protective custody for mailing explosives.
An Associate Warden at MCC New York visited Jeffrey Epstein in the SHU on Thursday, August 8, 2019, and reported he showed no signs of distress, anxiety, depression, or suicidal ideation.

Palm Beach County Sheriff Ric L. Bradshaw formally requested Florida Governor Ron DeSantis to have the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) assume the criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's prior incarceration and work release.

Governor Ron DeSantis issued Executive Order 19-183 on August 6, 2019, reassigning the Epstein case from Palm Beach County State Attorney David Aronberg to State Attorney Bruce Colton of the 19th Judicial Circuit.

Defense attorney Bruce Barket, representing inmate Nicholas Tartaglione, requested that investigators not interview Tartaglione about an incident involving Epstein without his permission, and was later informed no charges would be filed against his client.

Email correspondence shows coordination between the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office and FDLE in mid-August 2019, with FDLE taking the lead on the investigation into Epstein's time in Florida custody.
Jeffrey Epstein died on the morning of August 10, 2019, in the Special Housing Unit of the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York from an apparent suicide.
At the time of his death, Epstein was alone in his cell; his cellmate, Efrain Reyes, had left for court the previous day and did not return.
The FBI and the Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General immediately opened investigations into the incident.
Critical evidence, including computer hard drives from the Special Housing Unit, was removed and replaced on the night of Epstein's death.
The Bureau of Prisons later refused to release any investigation reports to the U.S. Marshals, citing the ongoing nature of the investigations.

The report is an interim psychological reconstruction of Jeffrey Epstein's death, severely limited because the FBI confiscated the original video of the incident and formal interviews were not conducted at the DOJ's direction.
Epstein was found dead in his single-occupancy SHU cell on August 10, 2019, after his cellmate did not return from court the previous evening and staff failed to assign him a new cellmate.
Correctional Officers Tova Noel and Michael Thomas admitted to not completing mandatory 30-minute rounds at 3:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. on the morning of Epstein's death.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found with a cloth around his neck but denied it was a suicide attempt; an investigation was inconclusive on whether it was self-harm or an assault.

The report identifies widespread systemic failures: inaccurate SENTRY housing assignments, missing or falsified logbook entries, unmonitored phone calls, and a lack of psychological expertise in cellmate placement decisions.
On August 6, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein's attorney complained he had no toilet paper, his CPAP machine was unplugged, and he had only made two monitored phone calls since arriving at MCC New York.
On July 25, 2019, a BOP attorney formally requested all documents and photos related to an investigation of an 'incident' involving Epstein that occurred earlier that week.
Following Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, the BOP initiated an investigation and sought his prior prison records from Florida.
Internal BOP emails show coordination regarding delivering Epstein's CPAP machine and scheduling a follow-up meeting about him in January 2020.
The document reveals ongoing administrative and legal concerns about Epstein's welfare and conditions in the MCC prior to his death.
On August 10, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York at around 6:30 a.m. and was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:37 a.m. from an apparent suicide.
Just days before his death, Epstein's attorneys complained to MCC staff that he lacked toilet paper, his CPAP machine was unplugged, and he had only made two monitored phone calls.
The FBI and the DOJ Office of the Inspector General were actively investigating the incident surrounding Epstein's death, as per the Warden's notification.
Internal BOP emails from November 2019 show a request for any reports prepared in the investigation of Epstein's death, indicating an ongoing internal review.
A "Psychological Reconstruction" report regarding Epstein (inmate #76318-054) was circulated within the BOP in September 2019.
Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019, while in pretrial custody at MCC New York on federal sex trafficking charges.
The reconstruction was severely limited because the FBI confiscated the original video of the incident and formal interviews were not conducted to avoid interfering with other DOJ investigations.
Epstein had a prior incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a cloth around his neck; he denied it was a suicide attempt and claimed his cellmate tried to kill him.
On the night of his death, Epstein was single-celled because his cellmate did not return from court, and staff failed to complete proper 30-minute rounds.

The report identifies numerous systemic failures: inaccurate SENTRY cell assignments, improper documentation, lack of staff training, and failure to consider sex-offender specific risk factors in housing decisions.

On July 22, 2019, Epstein's attorney complained he was denied promised bathroom access during legal visits, had not received two promised social phone calls, and was forced to eat vending machine snacks as he couldn't return to his cell for meals.
On August 10, 2019, the BOP reported Epstein was taken to the hospital after 'another apparent suicide attempt' and later confirmed his death.

Prosecutors expressed frustration that the BOP issued a public press release about Epstein's death before providing basic facts (time, cause) to the U.S. Attorney's Office for relay to defense counsel and family.
The email correspondence shows internal MCC communications involving the Chief Psychologist and supervisory staff attorney regarding inmate management issues.
Jeffrey Epstein died on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

There was significant confusion and frustration among U.S. Attorney's Office and U.S. Marshals Service officials, who were learning details from the press before receiving official information from the Bureau of Prisons.
Epstein had a prior documented suicide attempt on July 23, 2019, at 1:27 AM in the Special Housing Unit of the MCC.
Epstein's cellmate at the time of the July 23 incident was Nicholas Tartaglione, who was also photographed as part of the investigation.
On July 25, 2019, the U.S. Attorney's Office formally requested investigative documents and photos related to the July 23 incident, which were subsequently provided.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his MCC cell with an orange homemade rope around his neck in an apparent suicide attempt, but was revived.
Epstein accused his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, of attempting to kill him, harassing him, and trying to extort money, claiming he had only told his attorney about these threats.
Epstein died on August 10, 2019, after being found unresponsive in his cell with 'circumferential bruising around the neck'; resuscitation efforts, including CPR and intubation, were unsuccessful.
Medical records from July 30, 2019, show Epstein reported health issues including sleep apnea (without his CPAP machine), hypertension, numbness in his arm, and prediabetes.

Multiple prison staff filed memoranda describing the July 23 incident, with some noting Epstein's erratic behavior after being revived, including pretending to be unconscious and then giving a 'thumbs up'.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck. Custody staff reported it as a self-inflicted injury, and he was placed on suicide watch.
Epstein repeatedly refused to explain how the neck injury occurred but hinted on July 24 that his cellmate "had to do with what happened," though he would not provide details.
Following the neck incident, Epstein reported neurological symptoms including right arm numbness and temporary loss of control, leading to a cervical spine X-ray being ordered.
The medical records show Epstein had multiple chronic conditions being managed in prison, including prediabetes, hypertension, sleep apnea, and hyperlipidemia.
The documents are official Bureau of Prisons health service records created in the weeks prior to Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, documenting his physical state and a significant prior incident.

Epstein's medical records from July 2019 document multiple chronic health issues: severe L4-L5 spinal stenosis causing shooting back pain, hyperlipidemia (triglycerides 431), obstructive sleep apnea requiring CPAP, and constipation.
Epstein stated he had his CPAP machine with him when he was arrested, but it is not indicated in these records if he had access to it in custody.
During his intake health screen on July 6, 2019, Epstein reported having 10 or more female sexual partners in the last 5 years, sometimes using condoms, and a history of chlamydia in 2015.

The records show a consistent medical management plan was being implemented, including prescriptions for pain (Medrol), lipids (Vascepa), and constipation (Colace), with follow-up appointments scheduled into 2020.
Epstein denied any history of mental health treatment, suicide attempts, or substance abuse during his intake evaluations.
Jeffrey Epstein's BOP medical records show he had multiple chronic health conditions including sleep apnea, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, prediabetes, low back pain, and constipation.
A medical record dated August 10, 2019, lists 'Injury, unspecified' with the comment 'R/O self inflicted injuries,' indicating medical staff were ruling out self-harm.
Epstein was prescribed regular insulin on a sliding scale in late July and early August 2019, indicating his blood glucose levels required medical management.
The records document a CPAP machine was issued to him for sleep apnea on July 30, 2019, and he had a documented fish allergy.
The records were compiled and generated for the Office of General Counsel (OGC) by Tamara Allen on May 11, 2020, after Epstein's death.

Epstein was prescribed multiple medications including bisacodyl, docusate sodium, milk of magnesia, methylprednisolone, omega-3 (Vascepa), and insulin during his incarceration from July to August 2019.

A suicide risk assessment on August 1, 2019, noted static risk factors including high-profile crime, lack of family connections, and sex offender status, but concluded overall acute suicide risk was low.

Epstein was found with a string loosely tied around his neck in his SHU cell on July 23, 2019, though he stated he did not remember anything about it and it was unclear if he or someone else placed it there.
Psychological records indicate Epstein spent his days and evenings with his attorneys in the attorney conference room and had regular visits from them.
Medical records document Epstein had a CPAP machine for sleep apnea (serial # P11312813B1ED) and was on complete bed rest with bathroom privileges only at times.
Jeffrey Epstein was charged with 'Tattooing or Self-Mutilation' (BOP code 228) on July 23, 2019, after being found with marks on his neck.
Epstein repeatedly stated he could not remember how he sustained the injuries to his neck, attributing memory issues to sleep apnea and sleep deprivation.

Clinical notes from late July 2019 show Epstein had extreme anxiety about returning to the SHU due to noise preventing sleep, which he claimed caused him to sleep only about 30 minutes per night for five days prior to the neck injury incident.
A psychologist found Epstein competent to proceed with the disciplinary process related to the neck injury incident report.
Epstein's psychological observation was discontinued on July 30, 2019, with plans to return him to the SHU with an appropriate cellmate.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch.

Epstein consistently claimed to have no memory of how the string got around his neck or how he sustained the resulting marks and scabs, describing a lapse in memory between getting water and waking up.

Prison logs noted that Epstein told staff his cellmate tried to kill him, a statement he did not repeat to the assessing psychologists and which he later vaguely attributed to possibly being 'a joke'.
Clinical assessments noted Epstein adamantly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plans, stating he was invested in fighting his legal case and wanted to live.
Epstein expressed fear for his safety in the SHU, reported his cellmate had called him a 'pedophile', and requested housing in general population rather than administrative segregation.

On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck and a circular line on his neck, but he claimed no memory of the event. It was noted as unclear if he did it himself or if someone else did.

Epstein was placed on suicide watch following the neck incident and assessed as having a 'Moderate' overall acute suicide risk, with risk factors including his high-profile crime, sex offender status, lack of family connections, and current physical pain (sore throat).
Throughout the documented period (July 9-24, 2019), Epstein consistently denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan to multiple psychologists.

Epstein made numerous complaints about his prison conditions, including lack of property, cold cells, uniform issues, desire for single-cell housing, and problems receiving medication (Colace), soap, and spoons.

The psychological assessments concluded Epstein had no history of mental health treatment, no current diagnosis, and was psychologically stable, classifying him as CARE1-MH (no significant mental illness requiring regular intervention).

On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein's suicide risk as 'Low' for acute risk and 'Absent' for chronic risk, despite identifying risk factors like his high-profile case and lack of close family.
Epstein explicitly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan, and was described as future-oriented, cooperative, and with a clear mental status.
Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation on July 8, 2019, after returning from a court proceeding that may have contained bad legal news.
The assessment notes Epstein's only family is a brother with whom he is not close, and that he has a support system of friends and associates in the community.
Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney, anticipated an upcoming bail hearing, and stated, 'being alive is fun.'

On July 9, 2019, a BOP psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having a 'Low' overall acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk, despite noting risk factors like his high-profile case and lack of family connection.
Epstein explicitly denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan, was described as 'future-oriented,' and mentioned an upcoming bail hearing where he believed he would be released.
